metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C++ Vectors
C++ Vector
A vector in C++ is like a resizable array .
content.html: A vector in C++ is like a resizable array.

content.text: Both vectors and arrays are data structures used to store multiple elements of the same data type .
content.html: Both vectors and arrays are data structures used to store multiple elements of the same data type.

content.text: The difference between an array and a vector, is that the size of an array cannot be modified (you cannot add or remove elements from an array). A vector however, can grow or shrink in size as needed.
content.html: The difference between an array and a vector, is that the size of an array cannot be modified (you cannot add or remove elements from an array). A vector however, can grow or shrink in size as needed.

content.text: To use a vector, you have to include the <vector> header file:
content.html: To use a vector, you have to include the <vector> header file:

content.code_html:
// Include the vector library
#include <vector>

content.text: Create a Vector
To create a vector, use the vector keyword, and specify the type of values it should store within angle brackets <> and then the name of the vector, like: vector < type > vectorName .
content.html: To create a vector, use the vector keyword, and specify the type of values it should store within angle brackets <> and then the name of the vector, like: vector<type> vectorName.

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars;
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code: // Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars;

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars;
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings
vector<string> cars;

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars;
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.text: If you want to add elements at the time of declaration, place them in a comma-separated list, inside curly braces {} , just like with arrays:
content.html: If you want to add elements at the time of declaration, place them in a comma-separated list, inside curly braces {}, just like with arrays:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Print vector elements
 for (string car : cars) {
  cout << car << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.text: Note: The type of the vector ( string in our example) cannot be changed after its been declared.
content.html: Note: The type of the vector (string in our example) cannot be changed after its been declared.

content.text: Access a Vector
You can access a vector element by referring to the index number inside square brackets [] .
content.html: You can access a vector element by referring to the index number inside square brackets [].

content.text: Vectors, like arrays, are 0-indexed, meaning that [0] is the first element, [1] is the second element, and so on:
content.html: Vectors, like arrays, are 0-indexed, meaning that [0] is the first element, [1] is the second element, and so on:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", 
  "Ford", "Mazda"};// Get the first element
  cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo// Get the 
  second element
  cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code:
// Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW",
"Ford", "Mazda"};// Get the first element
cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo// Get the
second element
cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", 
 "Ford", "Mazda"};// Get the first element
  cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo// Get the 
  second element
  cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Get the first element
 cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo

// Get the second element
 cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", 
  "Ford", "Mazda"};// Get the first element
  cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo// Get the 
  second element
  cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.text: One advantage of using the vector library, is that it includes many useful functions. For example, you can access the first or the last element of a vector with the .front() and .back() functions:
content.html: One advantage of using the vector library, is that it includes many useful functions. For example, you can access the first or the last element of a vector with the .front() and .back() functions:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Get the first element
 cout << cars.front();

// Get the last element
 cout << cars.back();

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.text: To access an element at a specified index, you can use the .at() function and specify the index number:
content.html: To access an element at a specified index, you can use the .at() function and specify the index number:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Get the second element
 cout << cars.at(1);

// Get the third element
 cout << cars.at(2);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.text: Note: The .at() function is often preferred over square brackets [] because it lets you know if an error occurs.
content.html: Note: The .at() function is often preferred over square brackets [] because it lets you know if an error occurs.

content.text: For example if the element is out of range:
content.html: For example if the element is out of range:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Try to access an element that does not exist (throws an error message)
cout << cars.at(6);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.text: Change a Vector Element
To change the value of a specific element, you can refer to the index number:
content.html: To change the value of a specific element, you can refer to the index number:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

syntax_highlighting.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Change the value of the first element
cars[0] = "Opel";

cout << cars[0];  // Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

content.text: However, it is safer to use the .at() function:
content.html: However, it is safer to use the .at() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

syntax_highlighting.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Change the value of the first element
 cars.at(0) = "Opel";

cout << cars.at(0);  // Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

content.text: Add Vector Elements
The biggest difference between a vector and an array is that vectors can grow dynamically. That means you can add or remove elements from the vector.
content.html: The biggest difference between a vector and an array is that vectors can grow dynamically. That means you can add or remove elements from the vector.

content.text: To add an element to the vector, you can use the .push_back() function, which will add an element at the end of the vector:
content.html: To add an element to the vector, you can use the .push_back() function, which will add an element at the end of the vector:

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
cars.push_back("Tesla");

content.text: You can add as many elements as you want:
content.html: You can add as many elements as you want:

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
cars.push_back("Tesla");
cars.push_back("VW");
cars.push_back("Mitsubishi");
cars.push_back("Mini");

content.text: Remove Vector Elements
To remove an element from the vector, you can use the .pop_back() function, which removes an element from the end of the vector:
content.html: To remove an element from the vector, you can use the .pop_back() function, which removes an element from the end of the vector:

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
cars.pop_back();

content.text: Note: Elements are usually only added and removed from the end of the vector. If you need to add or remove elements from both ends, it is often better to use a deque instead of a vector.
content.html: Note: Elements are usually only added and removed from the end of the vector. If you need to add or remove elements from both ends, it is often better to use a deque instead of a vector.

content.text: Vector Size
To find out how many elements a vector has, use the .size() function:
content.html: To find out how many elements a vector has, use the .size() function:

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
cout << cars.size();  // Outputs 4

content.text: Check if a Vector is Empty
There is also a function to find out whether a vector is empty or not.
content.html: There is also a function to find out whether a vector is empty or not.

content.text: The .empty() function returns 1 ( true ) if the vector is empty and 0 ( false ) if it contains one or more elements:
content.html: The .empty() function returns 1 (true) if the vector is empty and 0 (false) if it contains one or more elements:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
vector<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();  
  // Outputs 1 (The vector is empty)

content.code:
vector<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();
// Outputs 1 (The vector is empty)

syntax_highlighting.text:
vector<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();  
 // Outputs 1 (The vector is empty)

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars;
cout << cars.empty();  // Outputs 1 (The vector is empty)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
vector<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();  
  // Outputs 1 (The vector is empty)

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
cout << cars.empty();  // Outputs 0 (not empty)

content.text: Loop Through a Vector
You can loop through the vector elements by using a for loop combined with the .size() function:
content.html: You can loop through the vector elements by using a for loop combined with the .size() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};for (int i = 
  0; i < cars.size(); i++) {  cout << cars[i] << "\n";}

content.code:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};for (int i =
0; i < cars.size(); i++) {  cout << cars[i] << "\n";}

syntax_highlighting.text:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};for (int i = 
 0; i < cars.size(); i++) {  cout << cars[i] << "\n";}

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

for (int i = 0; i < cars.size(); i++) {
  cout << cars[i] << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};for (int i = 
  0; i < cars.size(); i++) {  cout << cars[i] << "\n";}

content.text: You can also use a for-each loop (introduced in C++ version 11 (2011), which is cleaner and more readable:
content.html: You can also use a for-each loop (introduced in C++ version 11 (2011), which is cleaner and more readable:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
  for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

content.code:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

syntax_highlighting.text:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
 for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

content.code_html:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

for (string car : cars) {
  cout << car << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
  for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

content.text: Tip: It is also possible to loop through vectors with an iterator , which you will learn more about in a later chapter.
content.html: Tip: It is also possible to loop through vectors with an iterator, which you will learn more about in a later chapter.

What is the main difference between an array and a vector in C++?
content.html: What is the main difference between an array and a vector in C++?

metadata.question: What is the main difference between an array and a vector in C++?

options.text: Arrays can store multiple data types, vectors cannot
Vectors can grow or shrink in size, but arrays cannot
Arrays can be resized dynamically, vectors cannot
